body_text.text: COPD is a serious health problem characterized primarily by irreversible airflow limitation and systemic inflammation, which represents a substantial economic burden in the world.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 1,2 Despite great progress in the treatment of COPD, drug therapies have not changed significantly.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 3 Therefore, the development of novel therapeutic drugs and strategies to improve the efficacy in treating this deadly disease is still urgently needed.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Bufei Jianpi formula (BJF), a traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), has provided effective relief of symptoms in patients with COPD.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Our clinical study demonstrated that BJF had extensive pharmacological effects on patients with COPD, such as alleviating the clinical symptoms of stable COPD, reducing the exacerbation frequency, delaying acute exacerbation, and improving pulmonary function and exercise capacity.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 4 Increasing evidences demonstrate that, in treating complex illnesses, including COPD, treatment formula containing multiple drugs with distinct but related mechanisms can usually exert synergistic therapeutic effects and amplify the therapeutic efficacies of each agent.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 5,6 In the previous study, we constructed a systems pharmacological model by combining active compound prediction, target prediction, and network pharmacology to clarify the active compounds and therapeutic mechanism of BJF.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Systems pharmacology successfully identified 145 bioactive ingredients from BJF and predicted 175 potential targets of the active components contained in BJF.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, we experimentally demonstrated that BJF was effective for the treatment of COPD and ventricular hypertrophy due to its inhibitory effect on the inflammatory cytokine, and hypertrophic factors expression, protease-antiprotease imbalance, and collagen deposition, in vivo.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 7 Systems pharmacology, as an understanding of the function of the biological system, provided a systemwide view of the therapeutic mechanism of BJF in treating COPD rats.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, we should provide more experimental evidences to validate the systems pharmacology predictions at system level.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Transcriptomics-proteomics-metabolomics-profiling techniques provide holistic approaches to reveal the complex biological processes and function of herbal compound recipe.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: [8][9][10] Transcriptomics has been used in many in vivo studies to find the whole genome, which, however, cannot provide the details of the alternative splicing or even protein expression itself.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Proteomics is a promising approach to directly study the expressed proteins and protein functions in a cellular context.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, metabolomics provides the metabolic information, that is, the consequence of the transcriptome and proteome.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 11 Thus, comprehensive analyses of the transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics datasets have the potential to provide a system view of the complex biological processes and function of herbal compounds.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 12 We previously analyzed metabolite changes in lung tissues of COPD rats, and identified 30 strongly regulated metabolites resulting from intervention by BJF treatment.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 13 In this study, we further analyzed the molecular effect of BJF on COPD rats using the datasets of transcripts and proteins derived from lung tissues.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Finally, the aim of this study was to integrate systems pharmacology, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data streams, which provided a system picture of molecular mechanisms of BJF in treating COPD rats.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Klebsiella pneumoniae (strain ID: 46114) was purchased from the National Center for Medical Culture Collection (CMCC, Beijing, People's Republic of China).
body_text.section: Chemicals and animals

body_text.text: Tobacco (Hongqi Canal ® Filter tip cigarette; tobacco type, tar: 10 mg; nicotine content: 1.0 mg; carbon monoxide: 12 mg) was obtained from China Tobacco Henan Industrial Co., Ltd (Zhengzhou, People's Republic of China).
body_text.section: Chemicals and animals

body_text.text: Thirty-two Sprague Dawley rats (16 male and 16 female; 200±20 g) were purchased from the Experimental Animal Center of Henan Province (Zhengzhou, People's Republic of China).
body_text.section: Chemicals and animals

body_text.text: The animals were reared in cages with free access to food and water under standard laboratory conditions.
body_text.section: Chemicals and animals

body_text.text: All animals were handled with humane care throughout the experiment.
body_text.section: Chemicals and animals

body_text.text: COPD rat model was prepared as described earlier.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: Briefly, 22 rats were placed in a closed box exposed to tobacco and repeated K. pneumoniae infections.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: 14 On week 9, COPD rats were randomly divided into two groups with ten rats in each group.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: COPD rats were intragastrically treated with normal saline (2 mL) and BJF at the dose of 4.84 g/kg per day.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: The healthy control rats were also administered intragastrically normal saline (2 mL) for the same amount of time.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: All the rats were sacrificed at week 20.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: The lung tissues were shock-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80°C before use.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: The components of BJF were as follows: Astragali Radix 15 g, Polygonati Rhizoma 15 g, Codonopsis Radix 15 g, Atractylodis Macrocephalae Rhizoma 12 g, Poria 12 g, Fritillariae Thunbergii Bulbus 9 g, Magnoliae Officinalis Cortex 9 g, Citri Reticulatae Pericarpium 9 g, Asteris Tatarici Radix 9 g, Pheretima 12 g, Ardisiae Japonicae Herba 15 g, and Epimedii Herba 6 g.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: The herbs were identified and prepared in fluid extract according to the standard operating procedure.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: The experimental protocol was approved by the Experimental Animal Care and Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital, Henan University of Traditional Chinese Medicine.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: The animal experiments were conducted in accordance with guidelines of the Committee on the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the First Affiliated Hospital, Henan University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, People's Republic of China.
body_text.section: COPD model, drug administration, and lung samples

body_text.text: For microarray analysis, six rats were used for each group for microarray study.
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: Total RNA was isolated from lung tissues of six rats from each of the three experimental groups by TRIzol reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) and purified using a Qiagen RNeasy Micro Kit (Qiagen NV, Venlo, the Netherlands).
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: RNA integrity was checked using standard agarose gel electrophoresis and ethidium bromide staining.
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: Purified RNA was polymerase chain reaction amplified using a First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Hoffman-La Roche Ltd., Basel, Switzerland) and labeled using an Agilent Quick Amp Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA).
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: Then, RNA was hybridized with Agilent Whole Rat Genome Oligo Microarray (4×44 K) and washed.
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: Finally, the slides were analyzed using an Agilent DNA microarray scanner (part number G2505B).
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: The raw microarray data were further analyzed using Agilent GeneSpring GX software Version 11.0.
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: Processed data were subsequently filtered for significant detection (Student's t-test screening, P,0.05) and differential expression versus COPD model rats (fold change, |log ratio| .1).
body_text.section: gene expression analyses with microarrays

body_text.text: Lung tissue protein was isolated from the three experimental groups.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: In each group, six rats were taken out for the analysis of protein expression.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: In brief, the lung tissues were lysed using the lysis buffer containing 4% sodium dodecyl sulfate, 0.1 M dithiothreitol, and 0.1 M Tris pH 8.0 and homogenized in a mechanical homogenizer (Retsch Technology, Haan, Germany).
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The lysates were clarified by centrifugation and then stored at -80°C.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: For proteolytic digestion, trypsin (Hoffman-La Roche Ltd.) solution (protein/trypsin ratio 1:30) was added to the protein solution and incubated for 24 hours at 37°C.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: To label tryptic peptides with 8-plex iTRAQ labeling reagents (ABSciex, Darmstadt, Germany), each of the samples was reconstituted with isopropanol individually, and the labeling procedure was performed according to the manufacturer's protocol.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: For strong cation exchange fractionation, buffers A (10 mM KH 2 PO 4 in 25% acetonitrile [ACN] at pH 3) and B (10 mM KH 2 PO 4 and 2 M KCl in 25% ACN at pH 3) were used as the mobile phase.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The peptide mixtures were dissolved in buffer A and then loaded onto a PolySULFOETHYL A column.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Peptides were fractionated using an 86-minute gradient from 0% to 100% of buffer B and monitored at optical density 214 nm.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Fractions were collected every minute from the retention times of 8-58 minutes.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Then, the fractions were dried, dissolved in 0.1% formic acid (FA), and used for liquid chromatographymass spectrometry (LC-MS) analysis.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: LC-MS/MS analysis was performed on a nano liquid chromatograph (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) coupled online to a quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometer (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany).
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: For the LC-MS/MS analysis, water with 0.1% FA and ACN with 0.1% FA were used as the mobile phase.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The peptide sample was injected into a pulled tip column (15 cm ×100 μm inner diameter) containing C18 Reprosil, 5 μm particles (Nikkyo Technos, Tokyo, Japan), and separated online using increasing amounts of acetonitrile containing 0.1% FA (mobile phase B) at 300 nL/min.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Gradient conditions were as follows: 5%-34% B (0-25 minutes), 34%-60% B (25-30 minutes), 80% B held for 4 minutes, and 5%-80% B (1 minute).
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The identification results were obtained from Mascot.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The criteria used for protein quantitation were as follows: two unique peptide hits, two quantitative peptides, and disabling of outlier removal.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The reporter ion ratio for each identified peptide was determined by Mascot.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The loess and global median normalization were used to process the proteomics data.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Data were log 2 transformed and analyzed on both peptide and protein level.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Statistical significance of observed fold-change ratios was determined by one sample t-test.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: P-values ,0.05 were considered statistically significant for proteins.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: Fold change higher than 1.0 is for upregulation or lower than 1.0 is for downregulation.
body_text.section: Protein expression analysis

body_text.text: The molecular function of transcripts and proteins was explored by BiNGO, a Cytoscape v3.1.1 plugin.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: 15 Pathway enrichment analysis of transcripts and proteins was performed using the Database for Annotation, Visualization and Integrated Discovery and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes database.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: We considered regulated pathways only as statistically significant, if the P-value was #0.05.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: We applied Metscape to analyze the integrated pathway of gene, protein, and metabolomics data.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: 16 We also applied ClueGO, a Cytoscape plugin, to explore the molecular function of the proteins.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: 17 In the MetaboAnalyst 3.0, the pathway analysis module combines the results from powerful pathway enrichment analysis with the pathway topology analysis to help us identify the most relevant pathways involved in the conditions under this study.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: 18 Using STRING 10, we generated interaction networks based on the overlapping proteins between the targets of BJF and proteomic measurements of BJF-treated rats.
body_text.section: gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses
gene/protein set enrichment, network, and pathway analyses

body_text.text: In the previous study, systems pharmacology successfully identified the bioactive ingredients and revealed the potential targets of the multiple components contained in BJF.
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: Subsequently, we validated that BJF was effective for the treatment of COPD and ventricular hypertrophy due to its inhibitory effect on the inflammatory cytokine, and hypertrophic factors expression, protease-antiprotease imbalance and collagen deposition, in vivo.
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: 7 In this study, to investigate the system-wide mechanism of BJF in treating COPD rats, we further examined the effect of BJF on transcriptional profiles of lung tissues.
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: Using microarray-based RNA expression analysis, we detected ~41,000 expressed genes in lung tissues.
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: There were 2,463 and 1,012 genes differently expressed at COPD model (versus control) and BJF treatment (versus COPD model) rats, respectively (Tables S1 and S2).
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: These transcripts regulated in lung tissues of COPD model rats could be mapped to various molecular functions such as regulation of oxidoreductase activity, nucleic acid binding, channel activity, fatty acid binding, glucose, or fatty acid metabolism ( Figure 1A).
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: However, transcripts regulated only in BJFtreated rats were mapped to several molecular functions, such as kinase binding, protein complex binding, and insulin receptor binding ( Figure 1B).
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: In addition, in the COPD model group, the regulated genes were mapped to many different pathways, such as fatty acid metabolism, valine, leucine and isoleucine degradation, and propanoate metabolism ( Table 1).
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: The genes regulated in the BJF-treated group could be mapped to adherens junction, focal adhesion, endocytosis, wnt signaling pathway, etc. (Table 2).
body_text.section: Transcriptomics analysis results of BJFtreated COPD rats

body_text.text: To characterize the protein expression profiles of rats, expression levels of proteins were detected using LC-MSbased proteomics.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Comparing to those in healthy control rats, 192 proteins were identified in the COPD model rats (Table S3).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: After the treatment with BJF, comparing to those in the COPD model rats, 191 proteins were detected in BJF-treated rats (Table S4).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: The COPD rats (192 proteins) shared 100 common proteins with the BJF-treated rats (191 proteins).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Out of the 100 proteins, expression changes of 42 proteins in the COPD model were inhibited by the BJF treatment (Table S5).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: These 42 proteins could be attributed to various molecular functions, such as oxidoreductase activity and antioxidant activity (peroxidase activity, catalase activity, thioredoxin peroxidase activity; Figure 2A), which might be involved in the therapeutic mechanism of BJF in treating COPD.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In addition, the 192 proteins regulated in COPD rats could be attributed to multiple molecular functions, including phospholipase A2 inhibitor activity, peroxiredoxin activity, and oxidoreductase activity, acting on the aldehyde or oxo group of donors, etc. ( Figure 2B).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In the BJF-treated group, 191 regulated proteins were mainly related to oxidoreductase activity, adrenergic receptor activity, receptor signaling protein activity, and extracellular ligand-gated ion channel activity ( Figure 2C).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In addition, the proteins regulated in COPD rats and BJF-treated rats were mapped to various pathways, such as focal adhesion, tight junction, adherens junction, and leukocyte trans-endothelial migration (Tables 3 and 4).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: COPD is known to be accompanied by pulmonary inflammation, oxidative stress, and muscle fiber dysfunction.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 20,21 These results suggested that BJF treatment could improve these COPD symptoms probably by regulating multiple molecular functions and pathways, such as oxidoreductase and antioxidant activity, focal adhesion, tight junction, adherens junction, and leukocyte trans-endothelial migration pathway.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: holistic views on gene, protein, and metabolite data
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In the previous study, we detected 49 and 30 metabolites regulated in the COPD model (versus control) and BJFtreated (versus COPD model) groups, respectively.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 13 These metabolites were primarily involved in lipid metabolism ( Figure 3A and B).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In this study, a number of genes and proteins were identified, which deserve further attention to their system functions.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Therefore, we further explored the system biological interpretation of the genes, proteins, and metabolites by integrating transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Using the Metscape software, we investigated the latent relationships of the metabolite, gene, and protein measurements by constructing the correlation network diagram.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 4A and B, according to the transcriptomics and metabolomics data of COPD rats and BJF-treated rats, we constructed two gene-metabolite networks, which were mainly related to lipid metabolism and purine metabolism.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Interestingly, a number of genes and most of the metabolites were involved in lipid metabolism.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Subsequently, we constructed two protein-metabolite networks based on the metabolomics and proteomics data of COPD rats and BJFtreated rats.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 4C and D, we observed that the protein-metabolite networks could be divided into two primary groups: lipid metabolism and purine metabolism, and more than half of proteins and almost all of metabolites were involved in lipid metabolism.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: To explore the system relationships of the transcript and protein measurements, we compared the significant pathways derived from transcriptomics and proteomics data of COPD rats, and identified three common pathways including fatty acid metabolism, propanoate metabolism, and valine, leucine, and isoleucine degradation (Tables 1 and 3).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In addition, the transcripts and proteins regulated in BJF-treated rats were mapped into three common pathways: adherens junction, tight junction, regulation of actin cytoskeleton, and dilated cardiomyopathy (Tables 2 and 4).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Integrating systems pharmacology, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In the previous study, systems pharmacology successfully identified 175 targets of the active compounds contained in BJF.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 7 To investigate the system mechanism of BJF in treating COPD, we integrated transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data streams with systems pharmacology to provide a globe view of therapeutic mechanism of BJF treatment.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In this article, we first analyzed the overlapping proteins between the targets of BJF and transcript measurements of BJF-treated rats.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 5A, there were seven overlapping proteins (VEGFA, SLC6A2, ADRA2B, gyrB, CYCS, ampC, and katA) between them, which were associated with various biological functions, such as vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 1 binding, chemoattractant activity, and G-protein-coupled amine receptor activity.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Subsequently, we identified eleven overlapping proteins (GSTM1, GSTP1, CTSD, MPO, HSPA5, CAT, ampC, kata,  XDH, SOD1, and gyrB) between the targets of BJF and proteomic measurements of BJF-treated rats.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

ref_spans.text: (GSTM1, GSTP1, CTSD, MPO, HSPA5, CAT, ampC, kata,  XDH, SOD1, and gyrB)

body_text.text: Interestingly, the molecular functions of eleven overlapping proteins were mainly related to oxidoreductase and antioxidant activity ( Figure 5B).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: However, no overlapping pathways were detected between the potential targets and transcript/protein measurements of BJF-treated rats.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Finally, we constructed a correlation network diagram to investigate the latent relationships of the potential targets and metabolomics measurements of BJF-treated rats.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In Figure 6, the results show that the network mainly consisted of lipid metabolism pathways.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: As discussed earlier, we constructed a system-level picture of the therapeutic mechanism of BJF by integrating systems pharmacology, transcript, protein, and metabolite datasets.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 7, the systems pharmacology targets and three-omics data were integrated, and the comprehensive picture was mainly consisted of four groups: lipid metabolism, inflammatory response, cell junction, and oxidative stress.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In the previous study, we found that the expression levels of interleukin (IL)-1β, IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor-α were significantly decreased by BJF treatment.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In addition, ERK, p38, JNK, and NF-κB were the potential targets of BJF.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 7 These results implied that BJF could achieve its ameliorative effect on COPD rats by suppressing inflammatory responses.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In this study, upon BJF treatment, arachidonic acid metabolism and linoleic acid metabolism were the significant deregulated pathways in lung tissues.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: In these pathways, the level of lecithin, linoleate, 9-OXOODE, γ-linolenate, LXA4, LTB4, and PGE2 were suppressed by BJF treatment.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Moreover, these metabolites, such as LXA4, LTB4, PGE2, and PGF2α, were involved in inflammatory processes in the airways of patients with COPD.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: [22][23][24][25] In addition, according to the systems pharmacology predictions, ALOX5 PTGS1/2, LTA4H, and AKR1C3, the important enzymes involved in these deregulated pathways were the potential targets of BJF.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Therefore, the results indicated that BJF achieved its anti-inflammatory activity by suppressing the lipid metabolism and the production of pre-inflammatory cytokines.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: The inflammatory responses associated with COPD are believed to be triggered by oxidative stress.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 26,27 In this study, we detected eleven overlapping proteins between the targets of BJF and proteomic measurements of BJF-treated rats, which were mainly involved in oxidative stress.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 28 For instance, the antioxidant proteins such as SOD1 and GSTP1 were involved in the pathogenesis of COPD, [29][30][31] which were upregulated by BJF treatment.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Additionally, increased myeloperoxidase levels are associated with rapid lung function decline.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: 32,33 In proteomic study, we found that the expression levels of myeloperoxidase were decreased by BJF treatment.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: These results suggested that BJF achieved its anti-inflammatory activity by regulating the oxidative stress status.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Moreover, focal adhesion, the overlapping pathway among transcriptomic measurements, proteomic measurements, and the potential targets of BJF were significantly regulated by BJF treatment ( Table 5).
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: For instance, FAK, PI3K, JNK, c-Jun, and ERK1/2, involved in the pathogenesis of COPD progression, [34][35][36] were the potential targets of BJF.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Overall, we demonstrated that BJF provided protective and therapeutic benefits against COPD by regulating multiple biological functions, such as lipid metabolism, oxidative stress, inflammatory response, and focal adhesion pathway.
body_text.section: Proteomics analysis results of BJF-treated COPD rats

body_text.text: Three-omics technologies have emerged as the promising tools to find the complex mechanism of TCM in the form of systems biology.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: 37,38 Systems pharmacology is applied to conduct a comprehensive analysis of the dynamic interactions between the components of TCM and a biological system.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Combining systems pharmacology, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data is becoming more important to detect the system-level therapeutic mechanism of TCM.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: However, attempts thus far to integrate system biology data streams have been met with limited success.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: In this study, we first characterized the transcriptomic and proteomic profiles of the lung tissues derived from COPD rats and BJF-treated rats.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The regulated transcripts and proteins were attributed to multiple functions, such as oxidoreductase activity and antioxidant activity.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The metabolomics profiles of the lung tissues were previously characterized, and the regulated metabolites were mainly involved in lipid metabolism.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Finally, we sought to obtain a comprehensive picture of systems pharmacology, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics data.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The potential targets derived from systems pharmacology and three-omics data were integrated, and the system-level results indicated that BJF achieved its ameliorative effect over COPD via mechanisms that might be dependent on its system-wide effects on lipid metabolism, inflammatory response, cell junction pathways, and oxidative stress.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: In summary, integrative application of systems pharmacology, transcriptome, proteome, and metabolome has potential implications toward understanding the system mechanism of action of TCM.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The International Journal of COPD is an international, peer-reviewed journal of therapeutics and pharmacology focusing on concise rapid reporting of clinical studies and reviews in COPD.

body_text.text: Special focus is given to the pathophysiological processes underlying the disease, intervention programs, patient focused education, and self management protocols.
